awd_titl_txt: CSU Alliance for Preparing Undergraduates through Mentoring towards PhDs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on increasing the participation of highly qualified underrepresented minority students in mathematical sciences doctoral programs by providing a comprehensive training and research program at the undergraduate level. It develops a network of eight campuses of the California State System located in the Southern California area.  These include Cal State Channel Islands, Dominquez Hills, Fullerton, Long Beach, Los Angeles, Northridge, Polytechnic Pomona, and San Bernadino.  Built on the cornerstones of (a) undergraduate research, (b) advanced course work and seminars, and (c) strong mentoring and aggressive recruitment, the project will identify and prepare selected talented and motivated underrepresented undergraduate students to succeed in mathematical sciences careers through a series of high-quality, personalized activities. These include (a) summer institutes that complement courses and expand students' mathematical horizons; (b) at least one year of undergraduate research projects for junior and senior math majors; and (c) seminars and rigorous and advanced mathematics course work. Eight mathematics faculty with experience in mentoring students from underrepresented groups will co-direct the project with support of the chairs and fellow members of their departments. With these activities and under the guidance of the faculty involved in the project, students will grow mathematically and develop their full intellectual potential. The project will provide them with a comprehensive education and training program that emphasizes the rigor of mathematical sciences and discovery.

By identifying talented and highly motivated students from minority groups, by addressing critical choices they face, and by providing a solid mathematical education to them, this project will make a significant contribution to increasing the quantity, quality, and diversity of the mathematical sciences workforce. The resulting increase in numbers and quality of minority students from our region (particularly Hispanic/Latino students) entering Ph.D. math programs will do much to lift other students' aspirations and encourage them to pursue careers in mathematics or with a heavy mathematical component. This change will positively impact the quality of mathematical education offered in our institutions' undergraduate program. In particular, this project will alter the intellectual atmosphere among faculty and students in the involved institutions and will have beneficial repercussions beyond the time-frame covered by the project itself.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: MENTOR THR CRIT TRANS PTS IN THE MAT SCI

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the CSU-Alliance for PUMP is to increase the number of under-represented students from the participating CSU campuses that enter graduate school in the mathematical sciences or related fields. The ambitious goal is to create a doctoral culture in these Primary Undergraduate Institutions through undergraduate research and rigorous advanced classes in order to prepare students to doctoral programs and/or to jobs in industry and research labs. The alliance started with eight campuses, namely Channel Islands, Dominguez Hills, Fullerton, Long Beach, Los Angeles, Northridge, Pomona and San Bernardino. During the life of the grant, Fresno, San Marcos, San Jose, and Stanislaus joined the project. 

PUMP students went through a residential and intensive summer program in their transition from lower to upper division courses and undertook research projects in their junior or senior year. During the residential program graduate directors from PhD granting institutions visited the program giving students information about their graduate programs and advice on how to submit a strong application. Former CSU students also gave inspirational talks. A total of 55 faculty worked on the project, supervising  research or teaching in the summer boot-camp. Thirteen graduate students worked as Teaching Assistants, running problem solving sessions and being mentors and role models.

The grant funded 184 students, with 82 of them being female. The program had an average of 65.83% of URM students and an average of 53.42% of Latinx per year. Significantly, only three of the participating students have not graduated with a bachelor's degree.  Some students went straight to PhD programs after graduation, while a few decided to get a Master's degree first. At the end of the grant, 52 PUMP students had entered doctoral programs while another 66 went to Master?s programs, which translates to 64.13% of the participating students going to graduate school. 

A total of 62 undergraduate research projects were developed during the grant period, which led to 20 publications in referred journals. These were published in the following journals: Journal of Theoretical Biology, Advances in Mathematics, Communications in Analysis and Geometry, J. Knot Theory Ramifications, Journal of Number Theory, Combinatorial Algorithms (Lecture Notes in Computer Science), J. Aust. Math. Soc, Discrete Contin. Dyn. Syst. Ser. S, Am. Inst. Math. Sci. (AIMS), International Journal of Combinatorics, The Mathematical Scientist, CODEE Journal, Involve, Dimensions (CSU Fullerton), Proceedings of Bridges 2019: Mathematics, Art, Music, Architecture, Education, Culture, Serdica Math. Journal, and the PUMP Journal of Undergraduate Research.

A significant outcome of this project was the creation of the  PUMP (Preparing Undergraduate Mathematicians for Ph.D.s), Journal of Undergraduate Research, which inherited the acronym of its parent, the PUMP program. PUMP publishes mathematics papers with at least one undergraduate student author. Initially, it was housed by CSU Dominguez Hills and now it is hosted by the California State University Chancellor's Office site, https://journals.calstate.edu/pump, where it can be openly accessed.  The journal is indexed by the two main international mathematics reviewing entities, namely, Math Reviews (MathSciNet) 

https://mathscinet-ams-org.libproxy.csudh.edu/mathscinet/search/journal/profile?groupId=8871 

and Zentralblatt fuer Mathematik (zbMATH) 

https://www.zbmath.org/serials/?q=pump+journal.

PUMP is the first mathematics journal in the California State University system to be indexed in either one of these. The journal has an international editorial board featuring mathematicians from the US, Canada, the UK, Belgium, Argentina, Japan, and Romania, and so far published papers from authors in the US, China, India, Finland, and The Netherlands. 

Students also presented their research in various conferences and workshops. All of them presented in the annual PUMP Research Symposium at the end of the academic year. Other conferences include The Young Mathematicians Conference, Nebraska Conference for Undergraduate Women in Mathematics, Pacific Coast Undergraduate Math Conference, Math Fest, Diversity Festival (UCI), and posters in the Mathematical Association of America regional meetings and the Joint Mathematical Meetings.

PUMP hosted its first Mentoring Workshop in Fall 2016, where faculty from all sort of institutions (community colleges, PhD granting institutions, private and state colleges) participated. Since then, every year PUMP Research Symposium had a section for faculty on mentoring. These meetings led to the creation of the Pacific Math Alliance (PMA), a broader network of mentors for underserved students in our region.

Finally, PUMP created a community of participating students. During the residential summer program we brought PUMP alumni for inspiration. These were former CSU students, with the same background that succeeded in their careers. They left the students with that feeling "iif they can do, I can too." After the summer program, students interacted through social networks and reunited some times during the year when they saw each other in conferences, and especially at the PUMP Symposium, where they felt at home again; the symposium also put together students from different cohorts. PUMP alumni always want to contribute to the success of the program, the PMA webinars, and volunteered to mentor new students. The PUMP community still exists and is active.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/14/2021
Modified by: M. Helena Noronha

Image
  • PUMP community at 2014 Field of Dreams
    M H Noronha
    Public Domain
    M. Helena Noronha
    PUMP community
